newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa widens losses on NY, spec selling.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa widens losses on NY, spec selling.

text.p: Cocoa futures widened their losses to end Thursday at session lows, pressured by New York's slide on speculative liquidation.
Traders said London's prices were also pushed lower by trade and speculative selling.
Benchmark September gapped seven stg lower as expected and was driven to a low of 1,020 stg in the afternoon when some buying support emerged. It still closed 26 stg down at 1,021.
Other months also posted double-digit losses.
September earlier battled with 1,030 support but this gave way after New York tumbled in early trading, battered by a speculative sell-off.

New York's September went on to hit a low of $1,536 a tonne before standing $35 down at $1,541 at 1644 GMT. The spec liquidation had been anticipated as speculators were believed to be net long more than 20,000 lots.
Despite the latest setback, London remained trapped in its nearby 1,020-1,060 stg band at the moment following the big sell-off on July 3 which saw values falling by over 100 stg in one day.
A breach of 1,020 support could see the market testing the important 1,000 stg level again.
In switches, Sept/Dec widened to 29-30 stg from 23-25 on Wednesday while Dec/March stood at 20 stg.
The U.S. second quarter grind data, due to be released at 1245 GMT Friday, were expected to show an increase of between four and nine percent, one trader said.
"But I doubt it will have a real impact on the market," he said.
In the U.S., most analysts said they expect the grind to rise by five to 10 percent, although forecasts ranged widely from a five percent fall to a 15 percent increase.
"Factories have been increasing their capacity and business has been good," said one. "I would expect the grind to be up to 10 percent higher.
